title: BGT: The Champions winners Twist and Pulse reveal how they plan to spend £100K prize money
text:
Twist and Pulse won £100,000 after their victory on Britain’s Got Talent: The Champions (Picture: ITV/Twitter/Getty)

Britain’s Got Talent: The Champions crowned its inaugural winners Twist and Pulse weeks ago, but Ashley Glazebrook and Ben Murphy haven’t spent a penny of their winnings yet.

The dancing duo took on Stavros Flatley in the grand final last night, and viewers saw the two friends triumph thanks to a high-octane routine with a surprising I’m A Celebrity and Love Island theme.

The prize on offer was initially £50,000 before it was doubled by head-honcho Simon Cowell. When asked what they’ve done with their cash, the boys told Metro.co.uk: ‘We’re just planning stuff that we want to do.

‘We’ve had so many big ideas over the years, like a big show and stuff like that. We want to invest it back into ourselves and the big ideas we have.’

The boys busted a move to some high-energy dance tracks (and the Love Island theme) (Picture: ITV)

The dancers revealed that they also recognise this opportunity as a massive launch pad for them back into the public consciousness.

‘We think [the win] is going to kickstart [us] to a whole new audience this time,’ they shared. ‘As well as people that have followed us through the years. It’s an opportunity to show everything we’ve got.’

The boys first competed on Britain’s Got Talent in 2010, where they placed as runners-up to gymnastic troupe Spellbound. In the nine years that have passed, they know there’s now an entirely new generation of fans just waiting for their next Twist and Pulse fix.

Simon Cowell doubled the initial prize for the contest to £100k (Picture: ITV)

‘All the fans that were there in like 2010 have kind of grown up to be our age now,’ the two friends said. ‘So we have a brand new generation that may have not known about Twist and Pulse so it’s incredible for them to kind of go back and research and see what we’ve done.’

Saturday night saw the dancers triumph over the father-son duo Stavros Flatley and winning £100,000 and the honour of being named the first winners of the series, which brought together some of the most well-known and successful acts from the Got Talent franchise from both home and abroad.

The first series of Britain’s Got Talent: The Champions was an eventful one; from surprise early-on eliminations to a Susan Boyle no show.

After the finale last night, though, that’s still got everyone to thinking we could be seeing a second run soon..
